By Lawrence Hurley
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Supporters of Merrick Garland
column2: President Barack Obama's U.S. Supreme Court selection
column3: on Tuesday launched a new push to persuade the Republican-led Senate to act on the nomination before the Nov. 8 presidential election
column4: but their calls fell on deaf ears.With senators returning to work after a seven-week summer recess
column5: Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid called the refusal of Republicans to consider Garland's nomination ""disgusting and repugnant.""""Republicans have deadlocked our entire system of justice because of the Republican Senate's dysfunction
column6: Reid said.Obama's nomination of the moderate appeals court judge has been pending without action for 174 days
column7: longer than any other Supreme Court nominee in U.S. history.The U.S. Constitution gives the Senate the job of confirming a president's judicial nominees. In a move with little precedent in American history
column8: Republicans led by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have refused to take any action on Obama's nominee
column9: insisting that Obama's successor make the pick.""The Senate is returning from the longest recess in nearly half a century
column10: and perhaps the Republican leadership was hoping that Americans had forgotten about the unprecedented obstruction of a Supreme Court nominee
column12: the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee.

column1: We Need Nine
column2: a White House-allied group
column3: will hold a news conference in front of the Supreme Court building on Wednesday with Democratic senators and lawyers who previously worked as clerks for Garland.Republicans sounded unconvinced.McConnell ""has been crystal clear for the last seven months
column4: an aide to the senator said on Tuesday. ""The next president will select the nominee.""

column1: The nine-seat court has been one justice short since the February death of long-serving conservative Antonin Scalia. With four liberals and four conservatives now on the bench
column2: an appointment by a Democratic president could end decades of conservative domination on the court.The White House has called Garland's confirmation a top priority for the legislative work period that began on Tuesday and ends in early October. In remarks last month
column3: Republican Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley indicated he could be persuaded by a large number of senators to take action on Garland in a ""lame duck"" session immediately after the election. His panel would hold any confirmation hearings.

column1: Some conservatives worry that if Democrat Hillary Clinton defeats Republican Donald Trump in the election
column2: she would nominate someone more liberal than Garland.But in a statement on Tuesday
column3: Grassley reiterated that ""the next president should choose Justice Scalia's replacement"" and said his meetings with home-state voters during the recess ""only bolstered the point that Iowans should have the opportunity to have a voice in the direction of the Supreme Court for the next 40 years."" (Reporting by Lawrence Hurley. Additional reporting by Susan Cornwell and Richard Cowan)"	['Clinton'

column1: By Richard Valdmanis and Grant Smith
| BOSTON/NEW YORK

BOSTON/NEW YORK U.S. companies that have expressed the most fervent public support for President Barack Obama's environmental agenda are also funding its biggest enemies - the scores of U.S. lawmakers who are climate change skeptics and oppose regulation to combat it
column2: according to a Reuters review of public records.Ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential and congressional elections
column3: the donations from companies including PepsiCo
column4: Dupont
column5: and Google reveal a disconnect between how these companies present themselves to the public on environmental issues
column6: and how they manage their political contributions to support business-friendly policy.

column1: Many companies active in U.S. politics spread their political donations broadly on both sides of the aisle and consider multiple issues when deciding whom to support.But inconsistency between a company's environmental positions and its political giving may point up a need for better oversight
column2: according to Jon Lukomnik
column3: head of the Investor Responsibility Research Center Institute. ""There really needs to be a process that looks at these issues ... at C-suite and board levels on a periodic basis
column4: Lukomnik said.The Reuters review covered donations made during the 2016 election cycle by the political action committees (PACs) of 30 of the biggest publicly traded U.S. companies that signed Obama's ""American Business Act on Climate Change Pledge"" in 2015
column5: a public promise to enact climate-friendly corporate policies and support strong climate change oversight like the global climate accord signed in Paris.The review found that 25 of the 30 companies are funding the campaigns of lawmakers featured on a ""climate deniers"" list that was put together by Organizing For Action
column6: a non-profit created by former Obama campaign aides to advocate his agenda.The list includes more than 130 members of Congress
column8: and is a who's who of the biggest opponents of Obama's plan to combat climate change. Some of those on the list dispute the label ""denier"" and describe themselves as climate change ""skeptics"".The list includes Republican Congressman Kevin Cramer of North Dakota
column9: an energy advisor to presidential candidate Donald Trump who once argued the Earth was cooling not warming
column10: and Republican U.S. Senator Jim Inhofe of Oklahoma
column11: who last year held up a snowball on the Senate floor as evidence global warming does not exist.The review found PepsiCo and DuPont's political action committees gave about half or more of the money from their top donations in support of senators and congressmen on the list. That amounted to $56
column12: 500 from the Pepsi PAC's 29 donations of $2
column15: 000 from the DuPont PAC's 19 donations of $2

column2: AT&T
column3: GE
column4: Verizon
column5: and Mondelez
column6: according to the review.Those levels of donations given to climate skeptics are relatively high given that the list covers about a quarter of U.S. Congress members.Officials from PepsiCo
column9: and Verizon did not respond to requests for comment. DuPont declined to comment
column10: and Mondelez referred Reuters to the press release announcing its participation in the climate pledge.A GE spokeswoman said the company supports ""elected officials based on a wide range of issues
column11: but we have consistently been outspoken about the need to address climate change and have invested over $17 billion in cleaner technology R&D over the last 11 years."" PepsiCo has also been working to become more energy efficient
column12: and now operates the country's largest fleet of electric delivery trucks. But it still has a sizeable carbon footprint: It produced some 4.1 million metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents in 2013
column14: according to its website. A more recent figure was not available.

column2: 6 and 19 contain language that may offend some readers)New Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte sought to defuse a row with the United States on Tuesday

Obama

column2: a strategy some say is designed in part to bog down Hillary Clinton if she becomes president. It is not uncommon for the Congress to take it slow in an election year and legislative delays could work in Republicans' favor if their nominee Donald Trump takes the White House in November.But the strategy will also pay dividends if it is Clinton who takes office on Jan. 20. She will be forced to deal with old baggage rather than focus on her agenda of infrastructure investments and immigration and Wall Street reforms.""If Hillary wins
